title: Stock Tank Oil Data Schema
description: The result of running a Crude Assay. For representative samples of Stock Tank Oil, an additional set of stock tank oil (STO) analysis tests may be conducted to provide measurements of viscosity (at temperature), pour point, cloud point, wax appearance temperature, paraffin content, Reid vapor pressure, total acid number, total sulfur, molecular weight, water content, and the amounts of lead, nickel, vanadium and elemental sulfur present. Note that in OSDU, StockTankOilCharacterization does not include SARA and High Temperature GC; those have their own SampleAnalysisTypes. Also, other forms of Elemental Composition are captured in the Elemental Composition Family.

SamplesAnalysisID.title: Samples Analysis ID
SamplesAnalysisID.description: The OSDU Identifier for this SamplesAnalysis.

SampleID.title: Sample ID
SampleID.description: The OSDU Identifier for the Sample associated with this analysis.

FluidConditionsID.title: Fluid Conditions ID
FluidConditionsID.description: Identifies the testing condition of the sample fluid, e.g. InitialReservoir, CurrentReservoir, StockTank, InitialSaturation (References SampleTestCondition).

PhasesPresentID.title: Phases Present ID
PhasesPresentID.description: Identifies the phases of fluid present in the sample, e.g. SeparatorLiquid, FlashedOil, OilWithMud, Gas, ReservoirFluid (references FluidPhasesPresent).

Stock Tank Pressure.title: Stock Tank Pressure
Stock Tank Pressure.description: Pressure recorded within the stock tank.

Stock Tank Temperature.title: Stock Tank Temperature
Stock Tank Temperature.description: Temperature recorded within the stock tank.

MolecularWeight.title: Molecular Weight
MolecularWeight.description: The average molecular weight of the sample.

Value.title: Value
Value.description: The density value at the indicated temperature.

Temperature.title: Temperature
Temperature.description: The temperature at which density was recorded.

OilAPIGravity.title: Oil API Gravity
OilAPIGravity.description:
A measure of how heavy or light a petroleum liquid is compared to water. It is expressed in degrees API (°API) and is calculated using the following formula:
API gravity=(141.5/Specific Gravity)−131.5

WatsonKFactor.title: Watson K Factor
WatsonKFactor.description: Characterizes crude oils based on their boiling points and molecular weights. It is primarily a measure used to estimate certain properties of petroleum fractions.

PourPoint.title: Pour Point
PourPoint.description: The temperature below which the liquid loses its flow characteristics, ASTM D97

FlashPoint.title: Flash Point
FlashPoint.description: Flash point measurement as determined by an ASTM (American Society for Testing and Materials) standard test. The flash point of a substance is the lowest temperature at which it can vaporize to form an ignitable mixture in air.

NitrogenBase.title: Nitrogen Base
NitrogenBase.description: The basic organic nitrogen in the sample, as determined by potentiometric titration (ASTM UOP269-10).

TotalSulphurContent.title: TotalSulphur Content
TotalSulphurContent.description: The total sulphur content in the sample.

AsphalteneContent.title: Asphaltene Content
AsphalteneContent.description: The asphaltene content in the sample.

WaxContent.title: Wax Content
WaxContent.description: The amount or percentage of wax present in a sample

ParrafinContent.title: Parrafin Content
ParrafinContent.description: The amount of parrafin present in the sample.

WaxAppearanceTemperature.title: Wax Appearance Temperature
WaxAppearanceTemperature.description: The temperature at which wax crystals first begin to form in a petroleum fluid. It marks the onset of wax precipitation.

CloudPoint.title: Cloud Point
CloudPoint.description: The temperature below which a transparent solution undergoes either a liquid-liquid phase separation to form an emulsion or a liquid-solid phase transition to form either a stable solution or a suspension that settles a precipitate

MeltingPoint.title: Melting Point
MeltingPoint.description: The temperature at which a substance changes from its solid state to its liquid state.

WaterContent.title: Water Content
WaterContent.description: The amount or percentage of water present in a sample

TotalAcidNumber.title: Total Acid Number
TotalAcidNumber.description: The quantity of acidic compounds present in a sample, also referred to as TAN.

SofteningPoint.title: Softening Point
SofteningPoint.description: The temperature at which a resin begins to flow.

SmokingPoint.title: Smoking Point
SmokingPoint.description: The temperature at which an oil begins to produce a continuous visible smoke.

FreezingPoint.title: Freezing Point
FreezingPoint.description: The temperature at which a substance changes from its liquid state to its solid state.

AnilinePoint.title: Aniline Point
AnilinePoint.description: The minimum temperature at which equal volumes of aniline and lubricant oil are miscible, i.e. form a single phase upon mixing.

SaltContent.title: Salt Content
SaltContent.description: The amount or percentage of sodium chloride present in a sample.

WaterSedimentContent.title: Water Sediment Content
WaterSedimentContent.description: The amount or percentage of basic water and sediment present in a sample.

DynamicViscosity.title: Dynamic Viscosity
DynamicViscosity.description: Also known as absolute viscosity, this measures a fluid’s internal resistance to flow when an external force is applied. It quantifies the frictional forces between adjacent layers of fluid as they move relative to each other. The unit of dynamic viscosity is the Pascal-second (Pa·s) or poise (P).

Temperature.title: Temperature
Temperature.description: The temperature at which viscosity was recorded.

ElementalAnalysis.title: Elemental Analysis
ElementalAnalysis.description: Elemental analysis involves various techniques to determine the composition of a sample. Some commonly used methods are X-ray Fluorescence (XRF), Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry (ICP-MS), Atomic Absorption Spectroscopy (AAS), Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical Emission Spectroscopy (ICP-OES), Neutron Activation Analysis (NAA) and Combustion Analysis.

items.title: Element Analysis
items.description: Elemental analysis involves various techniques to determine the composition of a sample. Some commonly used methods are X-ray Fluorescence (XRF), Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry (ICP-MS), Atomic Absorption Spectroscopy (AAS), Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical Emission Spectroscopy (ICP-OES), Neutron Activation Analysis (NAA) and Combustion Analysis.

ElementID.title: Element ID
ElementID.description: The ID of the element detected.

ElementalAnalysisMethodID.title: Elemental Analysis Method ID
ElementalAnalysisMethodID.description: The method used to detect this element.

FractionationAnalysisID.title: Fractionation Analysis ID
FractionationAnalysisID.description: Identifier(s) for the specific Fractionation analysis where asphaltene content is captured.

ReidVaporPressure.title: Reid Vapor Pressure
ReidVaporPressure.description: A measure of the volatility of gasoline and other petroleum products. It is defined as the absolute vapor pressure exerted by a liquid at 37.8°C (100°F) in a closed container.

CarbonResidue.title: Carbon Residue
CarbonResidue.description: Indicates the amount of carbonaceous material left after combustion, affecting refining processes.

RefractiveIndex.title: Refractive Index
RefractiveIndex.description: The refractive index of crude oil is a measure of how much light bends when it passes through the oil. This property depends on the density and composition of the crude oil. Generally, heavier crude oils with lower API gravity have higher refractive indices
